docs.lead_paragraph: CHARLES H. HURME, an engineer from Huntington Station, is 88 but prefers to describe himself as ''about 30, Celsius.'' He retired 26 years ago but still kayaks, swims, plays volleyball and competes on the ''super senior'' tennis circuit, where he is a national champion. He said recently that he had just returned from his 25th trip to Club Med, this one in Cancún, ''and I windsurfed every day.'' He has also attended 22 Elderhostels, learning about marine biology and snorkeling, among other subjects, and is now on the waiting list for a seminar on foreign policy in Washington, D.C.

headline.main: Trying to Find the Secrets to a Long Life

docs.abstract: Article on results of Long Island University longevity survey, which measured attitude, lifestyle, mental stimulation, social interaction, spirituality and creativity of Long Islanders between the ages of 80 and 100; 72 percent of respondents cite very strong feeling of independence, 66 percent cite active lifestyle; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when well-tended American dogs get braces for their teeth and antidepressants for anxiety and attend the church of their owners' choice, it may come as no surprise that a powerful political constituency has developed around a species once known mainly for chasing tennis balls in the backyard. Certainly, the National Park Service would not dispute the rise of canine power. Park police were called in to keep the peace when nearly 500 people jammed outside a packed hearing room here two months ago, banging on windows and chanting, ''No leashes! No leashes!''

headline.main: Loyal, Two-Legged Lobbyists Raise Banner of Dog Rights

docs.abstract: Dog lovers in San Francisco carry dog-rights movement to new extremes with angry protests against National Park Service's plans to enforce leash laws; photos; anthropomorphizing of four-legged creatures has come to city halls and courtrooms around country, paralleling surveys showing that three-fourths of pet owners consider their animals akin to children; countering trend are dog attacks that have prompted New York and other cities to crack down on free-range pets; horrific death of Diane Whipple changed sentiment in San Francisco, with more people speaking out for leashing of dogs in Golden Gate National Recreation Area (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Telling Dr. Inside From Dr. Outside'' (Money & Medicine, March 4) described the unpleasant surprise faced by many hospital patients today: While the hospital and attending doctor may participate in their employer's health plan, others who treat them at the hospital -- including anesthesiologists -- may not.

docs.lead_paragraph: The organizers of the meeting had hoped for 50 livery-cab drivers, but only about a dozen showed up. One driver had an explanation. ''Time is gold,'' said Francisco Taveras, using the Spanish version of the common saying, ''and there's no group that saying applies to better than a taxista. When his car is empty, he wants it full, and when it's full, he wants it empty.''

headline.main: Saying the Road Is Hard, Dominican 'Taxistas' Seek Unity

docs.abstract: Coalition of Progressive Dominicans holds meeting with livery-cab drivers, most of whom are Dominican, to discuss problems facing livery drivers; coalition's main goal is to unite Dominicans from different sectors of New York City economy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Alejandro Toledo mounted a platform to make his presidential campaign stump speech, he pulled a Chakana, an ancient Inca amulet, from his pocket and kissed it. The Chakana's black cross represents the cycle of good and bad times that break every 500 years, with the next upswing, according to Mr. Toledo, due to begin at his hoped-for inauguration in July amid the Inca ruins of Machu Picchu.

headline.main: In a Campaign Replay, a Peruvian Is Wooing Indians

docs.abstract: Alejandro Toledo campaigns for votes of Peruvian Indians in Andes; presidential candidate, with prominent Indian features and rags-to-riches story, has always used Indian symbolism in campaign appearances, donning Indian garb and featuring his wife, Eliane Karp, Paris-born anthropologist who speaks Indian langauge; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BIKE messengers get no respect. Traffic, bad weather, collisions, lack of health insurance and clueless pedestrians are all part of the territory. Throw sexual harassment into the mix, and you've got an idea of what it's like to do this job as a woman.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Argentine Congress moved quickly today to enact a part of the emergency economic package proposed by the new economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, in a move to thwart tax evasion. But legislative leaders refused to grant Mr. Cavallo the immediate unilateral powers to overhaul state agencies and pension and labor laws that he said he needed quickly to jump-start an economy that has been stalled for more than two years.

headline.main: Speedy Start On Emergency Economic Plan In Argentina

docs.abstract: Argentine Congress moves quickly to enact emergency economic measures proposed by new economy minister, Domingo Cavallo; refuses to grant him immediate unilateral power he requests; rival political parties begin to cooperate to try to revive country's economy, embattled for two years; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A lawsuit against Prudential Insurance Company can proceed on a claim that its health maintenance organization committed fraud by relying on actuarial standards rather than doctors to make treatment decisions, a New York State appeals court has ruled. The court also allowed the plaintiffs to go forward with a breach-of-contract claim against the H.M.O., the Prudential Health Care Plan of New York Inc. Legal challenges to insurance industry standards that determine length of hospital stay and whether doctors have the final say in those decisions are pending in several states.

headline.main: Metro Business Briefing; SUIT PROCEEDS AGAINST H.M.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: GUITAR CENTER INC., Agoura Hills, Calif., the largest musical instrument retailer in the United States, has agreed to buy American Music Group for $32.9 million in cash, stock and debt to enter the school band instrument market. CANADA LIFE FINANCIAL CORP., Toronto, has agreed to buy the group life and health insurance business from Ohio National Financial Services Inc., Cincinnati, to increase sales in the United States. Terms were not disclosed.

docs.lead_paragraph: Facing criticism that President Bush's tax plan is too generous to the wealthy and not responsive to the faltering economy, Republicans in Congress moved today to make tax cuts more favorable to low-income taxpayers and to get money into people's pockets quicker. The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Thomas of California, announced that he had rewritten two of the main aspects of the Bush plan to give more benefits to the less affluent. The committee is scheduled to vote on Mr. Thomas's proposals on Thursday.

headline.main: Republicans Consider Increasing Tax Cut at Low End
